title: ABC/2 Formula for Intracerebral Hemorrhage Volume
description: Predicts volume of intracranial hemorrhage from CT measurements using a simplified ellipsoid formula. Widely used bedside method for rapid ICH volume estimation.

parameters.name: hemorrhage_shape
parameters.description: Shape of the hemorrhage on CT scan

parameters.name: length_a
parameters.description: Greatest hemorrhage diameter (A) on CT slice with largest area

parameters.name: width_b
parameters.description: Diameter 90 degrees to A on the same CT slice (B)

parameters.name: weighted_slices
parameters.description: Number of CT slices weighted by hemorrhage area (C): >75% area = 1 slice, 25-75% = 0.5 slice, <25% = 0 slice

ranges.interpretation: Small ICH volume associated with better prognosis. Consider conservative management unless neurological deterioration occurs.
Moderate ICH volume. Monitor closely for expansion and neurological changes. Consider surgical evaluation based on clinical condition.
Large ICH volume associated with increased mortality risk. Surgical intervention may be considered based on location and clinical condition.
Very large ICH volume with high mortality risk. Aggressive management and surgical consultation recommended. Consider goals of care discussion.

references: Kothari RU, Brott T, Broderick JP, et al. The ABCs of measuring intracerebral hemorrhage volumes. Stroke. 1996;27:1304-1305.
Broderick JP, Brott TG, Duldner JE, et al. Volume of intracerebral hemorrhage. A powerful and easy-to-use predictor of 30-day mortality. Stroke. 1993;24:987-993.
Lee VH, Conners JJ, John S, et al. Comparison of ABC/2 with the Simplified ABC/2 Formula in Calculating Intracerebral Hemorrhage Volume. J Neurol Disord Stroke. 2016;4(1):1111.
formula: Volume = (A × B × C) / 2, where A = longest diameter, B = perpendicular diameter, C = weighted number of slices × slice thickness (cm)
notes: The ABC/2 method correlates well with planimetric measurements (R² = 0.96)
Measurement time averages 38 seconds, making it ideal for bedside use
Hemorrhage shape affects accuracy - works best for elliptical hemorrhages
For slice weighting: >75% of largest slice area = 1.0, 25-75% = 0.5, <25% = 0.0
Formula assumes π ≈ 3 in the ellipsoid volume equation: 4/3π(A/2)(B/2)(C/2) = ABC/2
